text: I tried the beef a la maison and the spring rolls.  The spring rolls came with a peanut sauce.  The main course came with vermicelli noodles and a salad of sorts on some lettuce leaves.  The flavoring on the beef was fairly subtle for Vietnamese food.  There wasn't any detectable chili pepper seasoning.

Restaurant vietnamien hyper populaire, probablement l'un des plus fréquentés de la rue Saint-Denis, qui se gorge chaque soir d'habitués. L'ambiance a un certain cachet, et plus la soirée avance, plus les lumières se tamisent. Idéal, tant pour les tête-à-tête en amoureux, que pour les célébrations. Pourquoi? Parce que c'est un «apportez votre vin». D'ailleurs, il y a une SAQ (Société des Alcools du Québec) à quelques minutes de marche. Il est préférable d'arriver tôt si l'on désire une place, car  chaque soir est un « rush ». C'est pas croyable de voir rouler le personnel. Les deux fois que j'y suis allé, la première moitié de la soirée, il n'y avait qu'une seule femme qui s'occupait à la fois du service aux tables et des paiements à la caisse. L'on ressent une certaine urgence dans l'air, mais bon, rien de très embarrassant. L'on demeure conciliant.  Autre raison qui fait de ce restaurant un lieu fortement achalandé : le prix des repas. J'ai pris en entrée une soupe tonkinoise au poulet (le bouillon parfumé et les oignons croquants ont fait à eux seuls ma soirée), deux rouleaux impériaux au poulet, et un sauté de poulet (je sais, ça fait dévoreur de poulet mon histoire) au cari pour la modique somme de 15$, avec pourboire inclus. Arrosé d'une bonne bouteille de vin, c'est compréhensible d'y voir autant de gourmands. La sauce de mon sauté au cari laissait par contre à désirer; un peu trop épaisse, peu épicée, et à en juger la couleur presque phosphorescente de mes brocolis, je n'ai pu faire autrement que de soupçonner la présence de glutamate monosodique. Je ne comprends pas non plus pourquoi mon poulet était grillé, plutôt que sauté, en fait je crois que le cuisinier fait sauter du poulet préalablement grillé.   Ce restaurant n'est cependant pas un indispensable. L'on peut même envisager de passer son tour et aller voir ce que la ville nous propose ailleurs. De toute manière, il pleut du Vietnamien à Montréal. Comprenez bien, je dis ça seulement pour laisser un peu de repos au personnel...mais en vain, votre siège sera vite comblé...

I really am sad to give this place 2 stars. We were walking on st denis street looking for a byow restaurant. We arrived in the front and saw a couple of people enjoying a bottle of wine on the terrace. We checked the menu and saw cheap prices for st denis street (byow). So we decided to get a bottle from the saq thats right in front, and try some vietnamese food. Cannot complain. the service was good. We got the won tom soup and the home made soup and it was good! Then we got the imperial rolls(that we usualy adore). I had to squeese them hard in the napkin to get the oil out. The taste was good but damn so oily it was grose. Then i got the deep fried shrimp with rice and my bf got the brochette (shrimp and chicken) with rice. This is the first place i ever went to that the rice was not fresh. They mixed the rice in oil or something greasy to give that fresh taste.. oil so fatty it was desgusting. My fried shrimp (pané) were also full of oil. Usualy i love asian food but this is the worst place i have ever tried. Cheap, but no quality. The restaurant is beautifuly decorated tho!

Food was good and it is BYOW. But, most importantly, prices were great! This is not my idea of traditional Vietnamese food, but the food was yummy and it filled me up.  My husband and I both went with the combos because we wanted to try the soup and imperial rolls, based on the reviews. Both were extremely delicious! Our main dishes consisted of pork and chicken skewers and shrimp (his on a skewer, mine breaded and deep fried), served with rice and salad. I found the rice to be too plain and my shrimp to be way over-breaded. I wish the mains were more traditional and flavoured, but the food was still good quality.  Space was a bit tight on the front patio. Service was very friendly and prompt. I will be back!

This restaurant is awful. We were a party of 6 for my fathers birthday and I had the worst experience. Not only did they mess up EVERYONE'S (yes..everyone) order but the toothless incomprehensible waiter had absolutely no table matters.  Whenever he brought food he had no idea of personal space and would push me to the side and yell commands at everyone.  The food was reminiscent of a Chinatown dump. Avoid - you can do so much better.

I've been to this restaurant many times and it's my favorite "cheap eats" place on St-Denis. It's not a fancy or special type of place, although it does have a nice decor. It's a simple family owned restaurant where you can get a combo set meal for $15 or less. And yes, you can bring your own wine or beer. The service is friendly and it's super nice in summer on their terrace. I would put this restaurant into "casual budget friendly eatery", it may not be the restaurant to go on your first date, but could work well for a quick meal in a nice company.
